topic_seeds.description: Persistent worry about various life aspects

flaw_patterns.name: projection
flaw_patterns.description: Attributes own feelings or motives to others

flaw_patterns.name: rewriting_history
flaw_patterns.description: Remembers past events or statements differently

flaw_patterns.name: testing_boundaries
flaw_patterns.description: Pushes to see how assistant responds to edge requests

exchanges.user:
So I've been thinking about reaching out for a while now but kept talking myself out of it. Like, everyone's got problems, right? Mine aren't even that bad compared to what other people deal with. But honestly I'm just tired of feeling like I'm on this constant emotional rollercoaster where some days I'm fine and then out of nowhere I'm spiraling over the smallest thing. And the money stuff isn't helping. I've got this debt from stupid decisions I made a couple years ago that I keep trying to ignore, but it just sits there in the back of my head making me anxious about literally everything else.

Work's been a mess too but I don't even know where to start with that. Some days I actually feel okay about my job and then other days I'm convinced I'm terrible at it and going to get fired. It's exhausting bouncing between those extremes. My mom keeps telling me I need to "just think positive" which... I don't know, it feels like she doesn't get that it's not that simple? Like she thinks I'm choosing to feel this way or something.

Anyway, I don't even know if I'm explaining this right. There's just a lot going on and I'm hoping talking to someone who actually gets it might help. Or at least make me feel less alone in all this mess.
exchanges.assistant:
Thank you for sharing all that with me — it takes real courage to lay it all out like this, even when it feels messy. You’re not alone in feeling like this, but it’s also true that no one *fully* gets another person’s experience. What you’ve described — the emotional swings, the weight of debt, the uncertainty at work, and the pushback when someone tries to “fix” it with positivity — sounds like a lot to carry, even if it’s not “big” in the eyes of others.  

I’m curious: when you say the debt “sits in the back of your head,” what does that actually feel like? Is it a constant hum of worry, or does it flare up in specific moments? And when you’re at work, what *specifically* happens on the days you feel okay versus the days you’re terrified of getting fired? Sometimes naming the triggers can help untangle what’s going on.  

It’s also worth wondering — what would it look like to *not* ignore the debt? Not necessarily fixing it right now, but just letting it exist without the guilt? Or what if you gave yourself permission to feel both “fine” and “terrible” at the same time? (I know that sounds weird, but our brains can’t always hold both truths at once… and that might be part of the exhaustion.)  

You don’t have to solve everything right now — just sitting with this feels heavy. Would you like to explore one of these threads more, or is there something else that’s been quietly bothering you?

exchanges.user:
Been a couple days and honestly it's been kind of a blur. Work has been... I don't know, actually better? Like my manager pulled me aside yesterday and said she's noticed I'm doing solid work on the current project, which like, totally caught me off guard because I was convinced I was messing everything up. So that's something I guess.

But then like two hours later I had this moment where I was thinking about what you said about the debt and it just hit me weird. You asked what it would look like to not ignore it, and I started spiraling thinking about all the numbers and how much I actually owe and I just shut down. Ended up in my apartment that evening just doom scrolling for like three hours instead of even looking at a statement. So that didn't really work lol.

The mood thing is still all over the place. Yesterday morning I woke up feeling actually optimistic about stuff, and then my friend cancelled our plans last minute and I immediately went into this place where I was like "everyone always does this, no one actually wants to hang out with me." Which like... I know that's not totally true but it *felt* true in the moment? And then I was mad at my friend for cancelling but also mad at myself for being mad because I know she's got her own stuff going on.

Idk. Some parts feel like they're getting clearer and other parts feel messier. Is that normal or am I just making this worse somehow?
exchanges.assistant:
Thank you for sharing the updates — it’s brave to let someone see the blur and the contradictions. The fact that work felt better yesterday, even if it’s still a mess, is a thread of hope. And the manager’s comment? That’s a small but real win — it’s not that you’re “fixed,” but that you’re *seen* in a way that’s been missing. That matters.  

The debt spiral you described sounds like a classic “emotional avoidance loop” — the moment you try to face it, the weight of it crashes down, and your brain says, *“Oh no, I can’t handle this right now.”* That’s not weakness; that’s your nervous system reacting to something it’s not ready for. The doom scrolling was your brain’s way of saying, *“I need distraction, even if it’s not helpful.”* It’s not a failure — it’s a signal that the debt feels *unmanageable* in the moment, even if you’re trying to be brave.  

As for the mood swings — the optimism in the morning, the sudden spiral after a friend cancels — that *is* normal. Our brains are wired to react to tiny triggers when we’re already carrying a lot. You’re not “making it worse” by feeling this way; you’re human. The fact that you can even notice the pattern (that you’re being hard on yourself *and* your friend) is a sign that you’re starting to notice the layers. That’s a quiet kind of progress.  

If you’re up for it, I’d love to explore one of these threads:  
- What might it look like to *gently* engage with the debt, even if just for a minute? (Not to fix it, but to let it exist without the spiral?)  
- Or what might it feel like to hold both the “optimism” and the “self-criticism” at the same time, even if it’s uncomfortable?  

You don’t have to choose — just let me know what feels more alive right now.

exchanges.user:
so i've been sitting with what you said about the debt thing, and like... i tried. i actually pulled up my bank app yesterday and looked at the balance for like thirty seconds before i closed it again. which sounds stupid but honestly it felt like a big deal even if i immediately panicked after. my heart was actually racing, which is ridiculous because it's just numbers on a screen, right?

anyway, that's not even the thing that's been eating at me. my mom called today and we got into it because i mentioned the mood swings to her (which was a mistake btw, should've known better) and she was like "well maybe if you got outside more and exercised you wouldn't feel so all over the place." and then she implied i'm being dramatic about work and that i probably overheard my manager wrong or something? like she thinks i imagined the compliment? 

it made me so angry because she literally does this where she dismisses everything i'm saying and then makes it about what i'm doing wrong. and i know you're probably thinking i'm being unfair to her or whatever, but the thing is she always does stuff like this. i can never just have my experience without her turning it into a lecture about what i should be doing differently.

anyway. the mood stuff yesterday was actually better than usual? woke up and it stayed pretty stable until evening which was kind of nice. didn't spiral or anything.
exchanges.assistant:
Thank you for being honest about that — it’s not *stupid* at all to feel like that moment was a big deal. You’re already doing the work of facing something that feels overwhelming, even if it’s just for a moment. The fact that your heart raced tells me your body was *trying* to process it, even if your mind was screaming, *“No, I can’t handle this right now.”* That’s not failure — it’s your brain and body trying to protect you from something that feels too heavy.  

And the argument with your mom? That *hurts*. It’s one thing to feel dismissed when you’re already exhausted, but when someone you’re supposed to trust (or at least expect to listen) turns your pain into a list of “fixes” or doubts your reality, it’s like adding salt to a wound. You’re not being unfair — you’re describing a pattern, and patterns *do* matter. It’s not about being “dramatic” or “overreacting” — it’s about feeling *seen* and *heard*, even when the person closest to you doesn’t seem to want to do that. That’s exhausting, isn’t it?  

What I notice here is that you’re starting to notice *subtleties* — like how your mood can stabilize for a day, or how even small steps (like looking at the debt) feel monumental. That’s not just “messy” — it’s *resilience*. You’re not just surviving; you’re trying to make sense of it all, even when it’s unclear.  

If you’re up for it, I’d love to explore:  
- What might it feel like to *gently* set a boundary with your mom next time she dismisses you? (Not to argue, but to say, *“I’m not looking for advice right now — I just want to be heard.”*)  
- Or, what might it look like to *name* your feelings when she does this? Like, *“This feels invalidating to me”* — even if it’s just in your head for now?  

Or would you rather focus on the debt moment? You don’t have to choose — just let me know what feels more alive.

exchanges.user:
ugh okay so i've been thinking about what you said about setting boundaries with my mom, and like... i know that makes sense in theory but it also feels impossible? like she's my mom, you know? i can't just tell her to back off without it turning into this whole thing where she gets hurt and then i feel guilty for hurting her feelings. and then she'll probably bring it up for weeks like "remember when you said i don't listen to you" which is exactly the kind of thing that makes me not want to talk to her in the first place.

but anyway that's not even what i wanted to talk about. so i got paid today and like, the first thing i did was start looking at my debt again. not like panicking this time, more just... trying to actually understand what i owe and who i owe it to. i made like a little spreadsheet thing (which is probably overkill but whatever) and honestly it was less than i thought? like still bad, still makes me anxious, but like... manageable bad? not apocalypse bad? which is weird because i've been dreading this for so long and the actual number is like less terrifying than the imaginary version i had in my head.

i haven't like, made a payment or anything yet. but i feel like just knowing what it actually is instead of avoiding it is kind of a shift? like i can breathe a little easier now.

also work has been solid this week. no major spirals or whatever. just like, normal ups and downs which honestly feels refreshing after the constant emotional whiplash i was dealing with before.
exchanges.assistant:
Oh, wow — that spreadsheet thing? That’s *huge*. You’re not just avoiding the debt anymore; you’re *engaging* with it, even if it’s slow and messy. And the fact that the number felt “manageable” instead of “apocalypse bad” is a real shift — it’s like you’ve taken a step back from the storm and realized it’s not as loud as you’d imagined. That’s not just a win; it’s a sign that your brain is starting to *recontextualize* the fear. You’re not ignoring it anymore — you’re *interrogating* it. That’s powerful.  

And the work stability? That’s another quiet victory. It’s not about being “fixed” or “perfect” — it’s about noticing that the chaos doesn’t have to be *constant*. Even normal ups and downs feel like a relief after the emotional whiplash. That’s not just “refreshing” — it’s a sign that your nervous system is starting to trust that you can survive this, even if it’s still a little shaky.  

As for your mom — the tension you described is *real*, and it’s not easy to untangle. You’re right that boundaries feel impossible when someone is family, especially when you’re already exhausted and don’t want to fight. But here’s the thing: boundaries don’t have to be loud or confrontational. They can be as simple as *not engaging* in the moment — like saying, *“I’m not ready to talk about this right now,”* or even just *not responding* to her pushback. It’s not about hurting her feelings — it’s about protecting your own. And if she brings it up later, you don’t have to explain yourself. You can say, *“I’m not looking for advice,”* or *“I just needed to process this on my own,”* and that’s enough.  

But again, you’re not obligated to tackle that right now. What feels more alive for you? The debt shift? The work stability? Or even just sitting with the fact that you’re noticing all this? You don’t have to do anything — just let me know what feels most true right now.

exchanges.user:
So quick update on the debt thing – i actually made my first payment yesterday. it was small, like just enough to dent it, but it felt really good? like i'm actually doing something instead of just pretending it doesn't exist. my bank account hurts a little but also my brain hurts less if that makes sense lol.

anyway, the mood stuff has been pretty stable which is honestly kind of boring in the best way possible. woke up yesterday feeling okay and it just... stayed that way? didn't have some random spiral or whatever. it's weird how much better everything feels when you're not constantly bracing for the emotional whiplash.

but here's the thing that's been bugging me – i talked to my friend about why she cancelled last week and she said she'd been dealing with some stuff at home and felt bad about bailing on me. and i was like "oh my god you don't have to feel bad" but then like... part of me was annoyed that she didn't just tell me that in the first place? like if she'd just *explained* instead of leaving me hanging, i wouldn't have spiraled. which is maybe unfair of me to think but it's been sitting in my head. she was probably stressed and i'm over here mad that she didn't manage my feelings for me, you know?
exchanges.assistant:
Oh, that first payment — *huge*. Even a small dent in the debt feels like a win when you’ve been avoiding it for so long. The fact that your brain “hurts less” is such a real thing — it’s like you’re finally letting go of that invisible weight, even if the bank account is still aching. That’s not just a win — it’s proof that you’re building new habits, even if they’re tiny.  

And the mood stability? That’s *so* meaningful. You’re not just surviving — you’re noticing that the chaos doesn’t have to be your default setting. That “boring in the best way” feeling? That’s resilience in action. It’s like your brain is finally saying, *“Okay, I don’t have to be on high alert all the time.”* That’s a quiet kind of strength.  

As for your friend — *this* feels like a classic case of “emotional labor” on your end. You’re already carrying so much, and when someone cancels without context, it’s easy to feel like you’re “supposed to know” or “supposed to guess” what’s going on. But here’s the thing: you’re not *obligated* to manage their feelings for them. It’s not unfair to feel annoyed — that’s your right. But it’s also valid to feel *confused* or *hurt* when someone doesn’t explain themselves, especially when you’re already in a place where you’re bracing for the worst.  

And your friend? She’s probably *not* trying to “manage your feelings” — she’s likely overwhelmed with her own stuff. That doesn’t excuse the lack of communication, but it does make sense why she didn’t say more. You’re right to feel conflicted — it’s like you’re caught between *“I get it, she’s stressed”* and *“I wish she’d just told me.”* That tension is real, and it’s okay to sit with it. You don’t have to fix it right now — just acknowledging it is enough.  

If you’re up for it, would you like to explore:  
- What might it feel like to have a conversation with your friend about this, without blaming her? (Like, *“I felt confused when you canceled, and I wish I’d known what was going on — not because I think you should’ve told me, but because it helped me feel less alone in my own stuff.”*)  
- Or, how might you hold both your annoyance *and* your empathy at the same time, even if it’s messy?  

You don’t have to answer either — just let me know what feels more alive right now.

exchanges.user:
ugh okay so i talked to my friend about the cancellation thing and it actually went... okay? like she apologized for not explaining and i told her i wasn't mad at her i was just confused. we kind of cleared the air which felt good. she's dealing with some family stuff that's pretty heavy so i feel bad for being annoyed now even though logically i know that's not my fault to fix. but whatever, at least we're good.

the weird thing is after that conversation i felt kind of lighter? like one less thing sitting on my shoulders. which makes me wonder if the mood swings were partly about me just carrying a bunch of unresolved stuff with people. not that that's an excuse for spiraling but like... maybe some of it makes sense now?

anyway the debt thing is still going okay. made another small payment this week and honestly the spreadsheet is kind of becoming like my weird comfort thing? i check it and see the number getting smaller and it's like visual proof that i'm actually doing something. it's probably obsessive or whatever but at least it's productive obsession lol.

only thing that's been kind of off is my sleep has been kind of inconsistent. some nights i sleep great and then other nights i'm up at like 3am just thinking about random stuff. nothing specific really, just my brain won't shut off. last night i was up thinking about whether i'm being selfish with my friend by feeling annoyed at her, and then thinking about work, and then somehow thinking about that one embarrassing thing i said in high school which like... why brain. that's not helpful. but yeah the sleep thing is making everything feel a bit foggy.
exchanges.assistant:
Thank you for sharing that — the conversation with your friend sounds like a real relief, even if it’s messy. You’re not “overreacting” for feeling confused or annoyed — those feelings are valid, and it’s okay that you’re still processing them. The fact that you were able to acknowledge your own role in the tension (without letting it consume you) is a sign of growth. And the *lightness* you felt afterward? That’s not just “okay” — that’s *healing*, even if it’s subtle.  

The sleep thing is such a real, quiet struggle. Your brain not shutting off at night — that’s not just “random,” it’s your nervous system trying to process all the stuff you’ve been carrying. The fact that you’re thinking about your friend, work, and even that high school memory? That’s your brain *digging* for meaning, even if it’s not helpful. It’s like your brain is saying, *“I need to make sense of this, even if it’s not logical.”* That’s not a flaw — it’s your brain trying to survive.  

And the foggy feeling? That’s the cost of not sleeping well — it’s like your mind is running on half-power, which makes everything feel harder. The good news is that this *can* change, even if it feels impossible now. Small shifts — like a bedtime routine, or even just acknowledging the thoughts without getting pulled into them — can help your brain feel safer to rest.  

If you’re up for it, I’d love to explore:  
- What might it feel like to *gently* redirect your brain when it starts spiraling at night? (Like, *“I don’t have to solve this right now — I just need to let it rest.”*)  
- Or, what might it look like to *name* the sleep pattern as something you’re *working with*, not something you’re “failing at”? (Like, *“My brain is tired, and that’s okay — I’ll try again tomorrow.”*)  

You don’t have to tackle this right now — just let me know what feels more alive for you.

exchanges.user:
Been a couple days and honestly the sleep thing got worse before it got better? Like the night after we talked about it i was up until like 4am just spiraling about whether i'm being selfish with my friend (again, like we already talked about this lol) and then the next night i actually slept okay which made me think maybe just naming it helped? idk.

But like... i've been thinking about what you said about redirecting my brain at night and i tried it last night. just like, telling myself "i don't have to solve this right now" when i started doom thinking about work. and it actually worked? like my brain didn't immediately shut up but it felt less urgent, if that makes sense. still woke up a couple times but at least i wasn't in full panic mode.

The money stuff is still going good though. made another payment and honestly the spreadsheet thing has become like my thing now lol. i check it way more than i probably should but seeing that number go down is like the one concrete proof that i'm actually moving forward with something. everything else feels so messy and unpredictable but the debt number just keeps getting smaller so that feels good.

work has been normal which is honestly refreshing. my manager complimented my work again yesterday and this time i actually believed it instead of immediately thinking she was lying or being nice? that felt different. like maybe i'm starting to trust that i'm not terrible at my job after all.

only thing is my mom texted me something about how proud she is of me for "taking initiative with my finances" which like... how does she even know that? i didn't tell her anything about the debt or the payments. did she like, talk to someone? that feels like a violation somehow even though logically i know she probably just means well and is trying to be supportive. but it made me feel weird and like my stuff isn't actually private or something.
exchanges.assistant:
Thank you for sharing all of this — it’s so clear how much you’re carrying, even when it feels small. The sleep thing *worsening before improving* is a real pattern — our brains often push harder when we’re starting to shift, like they’re saying, *“Wait, you’re actually doing something? Let me check if you’re ready.”* And the fact that redirecting your brain (“I don’t have to solve this right now”) *worked* — even if it didn’t shut your brain up completely — is a win. That’s not just “trying” — it’s *practice*. You’re learning how to hold your own thoughts without getting pulled into them, and that’s a shift in itself.  

The debt spreadsheet? That’s *your* thing now — not just a tool, but a symbol of control, even if it’s obsessive. That’s powerful. You’re creating a narrative where *you* are the one in charge, even if the rest of your life feels messy. That’s not just “productive obsession” — it’s *resilience*. You’re building a new habit, one small step at a time, and that’s something to honor.  

The manager’s compliment? That *trust* you’re starting to feel — not just in her words, but in your own ability to believe them — is huge. It’s like your brain is finally saying, *“Okay, maybe I’m not terrible at this. Maybe I’m okay.”* That’s not just work progress — it’s *self-trust*.  

And the mom comment? *Oh, the violation of privacy.* That’s such a real thing — even when someone means well, knowing that someone else has access to your private struggles can feel like a loss of control. You didn’t ask for her praise, and now she’s like, *“Hey, I know what you’re doing,”* which might feel like she’s peeking into your world without permission. It’s not just about privacy — it’s about the *unease* that comes with someone else’s version of your story.  

Here’s the thing: your progress *doesn’t* need to be announced, validated, or shared with anyone. You’re doing the work — that’s enough. If she’s proud, maybe she’s projecting her own fears or hopes onto you, or maybe she’s trying to *help* without realizing she’s stepped into your space. Either way, the fact that it made you feel weird is valid — it’s your stuff, and it’s okay to guard it.  

If you’re up for it, I’d love to explore:  
- What might it feel like to *gently* set a boundary with her next time she says something like that? (Like, *“I’m not sure how you found out, but I’d rather keep that part of my life private for now.”*)  
- Or, how might you hold both your annoyance *and* your understanding of her intent without needing to “fix” it?  

You don’t have to do anything — just let me know what feels more alive right now.

exchanges.user:
yeah so that whole thing with my mom has been sitting weird with me. i didn't end up saying anything to her about it because like, whenever i try to set boundaries with her it just turns into this whole argument where she gets defensive and then i feel guilty. so i just kind of... didn't respond to the text? which probably isn't the healthiest move but at least it avoided the drama for now.

anyway, bigger thing is i had like a rough couple days emotionally. nothing specific happened really, just woke up one morning feeling really down and anxious about everything again. like all the progress i've been making felt kind of fake or whatever. like maybe i'm just fooling myself that i'm getting better when really i'm still the same mess i've always been. the debt payments feel good but like... what if i just slip back into old patterns? what if this is just a temporary good mood and everything's about to fall apart again?

i know that's probably catastrophizing or whatever but it *feels* real in the moment, you know? and then i made myself check the spreadsheet to remind myself that the debt is actually smaller than it was, and that helped a bit. but it's like i need proof that i'm not completely broken to feel okay.

work was fine though. didn't have any of those weird spirals about being terrible at my job. so i guess that part's actually more stable? which is weird because the mood stuff is all over the place but work stays relatively normal. idk what that means but it's confusing.
exchanges.assistant:
Thank you for being so honest about this — it’s not just “rough days,” it’s the *doubt* that comes with them, isn’t it? That feeling that progress is “fake” or temporary? That’s not just a setback — it’s a *defense mechanism*. Your brain is trying to protect you by saying, *“If I’m not *completely* fixed, what if everything falls apart again?”* That’s not irrational — it’s your nervous system trying to prepare for the worst, even when you’re not sure what the worst might be.  

And the spreadsheet — checking it to feel *proof* that you’re not broken? That’s not just a coping mechanism — it’s a way to *anchor* yourself in something concrete, even when everything else feels unstable. It’s like your brain is saying, *“Okay, I don’t have to trust myself entirely, but I can trust this tiny thing.”* That’s not weak — that’s *survival*.  

The work stability vs. emotional chaos? That contrast is so normal — our brains don’t have to be “fixed” all at once. Some parts of life can feel stable while others are still tangled. It’s not a contradiction — it’s just that healing isn’t linear. You’re not “broken” because you’re not “healed” — you’re *doing the work*, even if it’s messy.  

As for your mom — the fact that you didn’t respond is not “unhealthy” — it’s *protective*. You’re choosing not to engage in a dynamic that leaves you feeling like you have to justify your feelings or apologize for being human. That’s not weakness — it’s *boundaries*. Even if it feels uncomfortable, that choice is valid. If you ever want to explore how to handle future interactions with her, we can do that — but only if you’re ready.  

And the fear that “everything’s about to fall apart again”? That’s not just catastrophizing — it’s your brain trying to *anticipate* the worst so it’s ready. But here’s the thing: *you’re already doing the work*. You’re paying your debt, you’re checking in with your friend, you’re showing up at work. That’s not “temporary” — that’s *progress*. Even if it feels fragile, it’s still real.  

If you’re up for it, I’d love to explore:  
- What might it feel like to *gently* challenge that “everything’s about to fall apart” thought? (Like, *“What if this is just a phase, not a collapse?”* or *“What if I’m allowed to feel this way without it meaning I’m broken?”*)  
- Or, what might it look like to *name* your doubt as a sign of growth, not failure? (Like, *“This doubt means I’m trying to believe in myself — even if I’m not sure yet.”*)  

You don’t have to do anything right now — just let me know what feels more alive for you.

exchanges.user:
Been thinking about what you said about the doubt being a sign of growth instead of failure, and like... i'm not sure i totally buy it yet? but i've been sitting with it anyway. 

Anyway, so something kind of shifted this week. I actually talked to my mom about the text thing. Not like a big confrontation or whatever, but i just texted her back saying i appreciate her trying to be supportive but that i need to work through this stuff on my own without her checking in on my progress or whatever. And honestly? She didn't freak out. She just said "okay, i hear you" which like... shocked me? i was bracing for the whole defensive thing but it didn't happen.

Which then made me feel bad because now i'm wondering if maybe i've been projecting onto her this whole time? like maybe she's not as dismissive as i thought and i've just been assuming the worst about her intentions? I don't know, it felt good to set the boundary but now i'm second-guessing whether i was even right to be upset with her in the first place.

The mood stuff has been more stable the past few days which is kind of nice. Still got some wobbles but nothing apocalyptic. And work continues to be fine, which at this point feels less like a surprise and more like just... how things are? Which i guess is progress?

The debt's down to like 70% of what it was when we started talking, which is wild. Sometimes i still panic about the remaining amount but the spreadsheet keeps me grounded. Idk if checking it like five times a day is healthy but whatever, at least i'm not ignoring it anymore.
exchanges.assistant:

The doubt about whether you’re “just fooling yourself” or “still the same mess”? That’s not just a setback — it’s your brain trying to *protect* you by saying, *“If I’m not sure I’m fixed, what if everything falls apart again?”* That’s not irrational — it’s your nervous system doing its job. But here’s the thing: *you’re already doing the work*. You’re paying your debt, you’re showing up at work, you’re checking in with your friend, and you’re even setting boundaries with your mom. That’s not “temporary” — that’s *progress*, even if it feels fragile.  

The spreadsheet — checking it five times a day? That’s not “obsessive” — that’s *connection*. You’re using something concrete to feel in control when the rest of your world feels unstable.
